content.title: Hepatic Artery Aneurysm

definition.primary: Abnormal dilatation of the hepatic artery or its branches, representing the second most common visceral artery aneurysm. May be true aneurysms (involving all wall layers) or pseudoaneurysms (contained rupture, often post-traumatic or iatrogenic).
key_concepts: Second most common visceral aneurysm (after splenic)
Increasing incidence due to hepatobiliary interventions
High rupture risk (20-40%) with significant mortality
Pseudoaneurysms increasingly common from trauma and procedures

epidemiology.prevalence: Represent 20% of all visceral artery aneurysms
epidemiology.trends: Increasing due to hepatobiliary surgery and interventional procedures

by_type.description: Involving all three arterial wall layers
by_type.common_causes: Atherosclerosis, medial degeneration, connective tissue disorders

by_type.description: Contained rupture with wall formed by surrounding tissue

by_location.surgical_access: More accessible for open or endovascular repair
Often requires embolization or hepatic resection

causes.notes: Most common cause of true aneurysms
Post-liver biopsy, cholecystectomy, hepatic surgery, TIPS
Bacterial endocarditis, IV drug use, biliary sepsis
Enzymatic digestion of arterial wall causing pseudoaneurysm

clinical_presentation.asymptomatic: 50% discovered incidentally on imaging for other indications

common_symptoms: Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain (most common)
Gastrointestinal bleeding (hemobilia if communicates with biliary tree)

quincke_triad.description: Classic triad of hemobilia (pathognomonic but rare)

rupture.frequency: 21% of true aneurysms, higher for pseudoaneurysms
presentation: May rupture into peritoneum, biliary tree, or GI tract

imaging.utility: Gold standard for diagnosis and characterization
imaging.findings: Enhancing mass in course of hepatic artery, size measurement, relationship to liver parenchyma

imaging.utility: May detect larger aneurysms, assess flow characteristics
Definitive diagnosis and simultaneous treatment option
Alternative when CT contraindicated, good anatomic detail

indications_for_treatment: Women of childbearing age (pregnancy increases rupture risk)

endovascular_treatment.preferred_when: First-line for most hepatic artery aneurysms

techniques.applicability: Standard approach, pack aneurysm sac to promote thrombosis
techniques.considerations: Need to occlude inflow and outflow ('sandwich' technique)

techniques.applicability: When maintaining hepatic artery patency is essential (e.g., post-transplant)
Adjunct to coils, useful for pseudoaneurysms

complications: Hepatic ischemia (usually tolerated due to collaterals)

techniques.technique: Aneurysm ligation with hepatic artery sacrifice
techniques.applicability: When collateral flow adequate via GDA, celiac branches
When hepatic artery flow must be preserved
Intrahepatic aneurysms not amenable to embolization

collateral_considerations.hepatic_tolerance: Liver can tolerate hepatic artery ligation if portal vein patent
exceptions: Liver transplant recipients (hepatic artery sole supply)

outcomes.natural_history: 21% rupture rate for untreated true aneurysms

content.statement: Hepatic Artery Aneurysm is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Visceral-Aneurysms that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Hepatic Artery Aneurysm helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Hepatic Artery Aneurysm include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Hepatic Artery Aneurysm.

learning_objectives: Identify risk factors and etiologies of hepatic artery aneurysm
Recognize clinical presentations including Quincke triad
Compare endovascular and surgical treatment options
Understand the role of collateral circulation in treatment planning
key_points: Second most common visceral aneurysm after splenic
Pseudoaneurysms have higher rupture risk than true aneurysms
Endovascular treatment is first-line for most cases
Hepatic artery sacrifice is usually tolerated if portal vein is patent
clinical_pearls: Consider hepatic artery aneurysm in patients with prior hepatobiliary procedures presenting with RUQ pain or GI bleeding
Quincke triad is pathognomonic but present in minority of cases
Always assess portal vein patency before planning hepatic artery sacrifice
Liver transplant recipients require hepatic artery reconstruction - cannot sacrifice
